docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate's approval on Thursday of a bill drastically limiting fertility treatments was itself freighted with issues of enormous importance to the nation's identity, like the size of its future population and the relationship between secularization and the beliefs of the Roman Catholic church. The country has the second lowest fertility rate in Europe, after Spain, and the highest proportion of elderly people, according to the United Nations Population Division. Earlier this month, in the hopes of persuading parents to reproduce more, the government introduced a 1,000-euro payment for every child after the first-born delivered before the end of 2004.

headline.main: Italian Debate on Fertility Bill Raises Issue of Church Influence

docs.abstract: Italian Senate's approval of bill drastically reducing fertility treatments is freighted with issues of enormous importance to nation's identity, like size of its future population and relationship between secularization and beliefs of Roman Catholic Church; country has second-lowest fertility rate in Europe, after Spain, and highest proportion of elderly people; government has introduced 1,000-euro payment for every child delivered before end of 2004, but new legislation blocks many routes toward pregnancy (S)
docs.snippet: The Senate's approval on Thursday of a bill drastically limiting fertility treatments was itself freighted with issues of enormous importance to the nation's identity, like the size of its future population and the relationship between secularization...

docs.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, in a major advance for women's health, the Food and Drug Administration approved the marketing and sale of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take within three days of unprotected sexual intercourse to prevent pregnancy. Now the agency must decide whether to allow an even bigger breakthrough, and permit the so-called morning-after pill to be sold over the counter in pharmacies, without a doctor's prescription. On Tuesday, the agency's advisory panels for nonprescription drugs and reproductive health will hold a joint hearing as prelude to a vote. The panels are supposed to be judging whether the drug, known as Plan B, is safe enough to use without medical supervision. Given numerous studies attesting to its safety, and the fact that millions of women around the world have been successfully using similar emergency medication for more than 25 years, advocates who have urged the drug's acceptance have a right to feel at least optimistic.
docs.abstract: Editorial urges FDA to approve over-the-counter sales of 'morning after' contraceptive (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Maurice Clarett raised the possibility of jumping to the National Football League as an Ohio State freshman, the first person I thought of was Andy Livingston. Livingston was the Clarett of my generation -- a talented teenager who wanted to play pro football. He is the skeleton in the N.F.L.'s closet: tangible evidence that a teenager can be successful in the league. In 1964, I was a high school freshman in Chicago and a big Bears fan. The Bears were coming off an N.F.L. championship, and many of us were intrigued by the presence of a 19-year-old rookie fullback who had been granted an exemption into the league.

headline.main: Sports of The Times; In 1964, a Teenager Showed He Could Play

docs.abstract: William C Rhoden Sports of The Times column discusses former Chicago Bears player Andy Livingston, who was granted hardship exemption to play in NFL without graduating high school in 1964, and proved that age does not have to be factor in player's success; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two panels for the Food and Drug Administration will consider early next week whether to allow the so-called morning-after pill, now a prescription drug taken after intercourse to prevent pregnancy, to be sold over the counter. But unlike other more ordinary hearings for drugs like allergy medications to be shifted from prescriptions, this hearing has become entangled in the thorny politics of abortion, raising questions of when a pregnancy begins and who decides.

headline.main: Debate on Selling Morning-After Pill Over the Counter

docs.abstract: Two panels for Food and Drug Administration will consider whether to allow over-the-counter sale of so-called morning-after pill, taken after intercourse to prevent pregnancy; hearing has become entangled in thorny politics of abortion, raising questions of when pregnancy begins and who decides; if approved, drug known as Plan B would be available in drugstores and anywhere else over-the-counter medications are sold; drug is essentiall two high-dose birth control pills; it can prevent up to 89 percent of unwanted pregnancies if taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse; it is uncertain how panels will vote or whether FDA will take their advice; panel includes some abortion opponents as well as staunch advocates of emergency contraception; Plan B's manufacturer, Women's Capital Corp, applied for change from prescription to over-the-counter status in spring (M)
docs.snippet: Two panels for the Food and Drug Administration will consider early next week whether to allow the so-called morning-after pill, now a prescription drug taken after intercourse to prevent pregnancy, to be sold over the counter.    But unlike other...

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. Now Playing * ''BAD SANTA,'' starring Billy Bob Thornton and Tony Cox. Directed by Terry Zwigoff (R, 95 minutes). Somebody needed to make a comedy built around all of the holiday season hostility that goes up along with the decorations at this time of year. Mr. Zwigoff and the screenwriters Glenn Ficarra and John Requa are just the guys for such a task. ''Bad Santa'' takes all of the Christmas season's bad vibes and converts them into an achingly funny and corrupt dark comedy. Mr. Thornton is Willie T. Stokes, a burned-out, hard-drinking safecracker who is annually roused from sleeping one off during the most wonderful time of the year by his dwarf partner, Marcus (Mr. Cox). As Marcus works as a department store elf, he also cases the store so that he and Willie can break in and relieve the joint of valuable merchandise. On this tour they have ended up in Phoenix, which just adds to the wealth of hilarious incongruity. As a director, Mr. Zwigoff has a taste for finding the dramatic power of self-loathing and making it entertainment. His previous films -- the documentary ''Crumb'' and his fiction-film debut, ''Ghost World'' -- both hinged on coping with epic tides of depression. ''Bad Santa'' falls directly into that lineage. Willie is filled with the most distorted kind of narcissism imaginable, and for Mr. Thornton it functions as a kind of star chemistry. Willie ladles it generously on the kids who line up to see him on his wobbly perch on Santa's throne: he's the kind of minimum-wage jackal who has sent his victims on to thousands of hours of therapy (Elvis Mitchell).

docs.lead_paragraph: Influenza is now causing widespread illness in 24 states, up from 13 a week ago, but may have reached its peak in some states with a high number of cases, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. The director, Dr. Julie L. Gerberding, said influenza had not peaked nationally. But while ''we are not sure yet,'' she cautioned, influenza ''is possibly leveling off in some states that have been hardest hit.'' She did not specify the states.

headline.main: Flu Illnesses Are Widespread in 24 States, Official Says

docs.abstract: Influenza is now causing widespread illness in 24 states, up from 13 a week ago, but may have reached its peak in some states with high number of cases; Dr Julie L Gerberding, director of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, says influenza has not peaked nationally; health and human services secretary Tommy G Thompson says his agency has bought last 100,000 doses of adult influenza vaccine from Aventis Pasteur and will ship it to states for use among high-risk groups; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Concerned that pregnant women, nursing mothers and young children could be exposed to unsafe levels of mercury, the federal government took steps yesterday to caution people in these groups that they should limit the amount of tuna they eat. The warning on tuna is part of an updated draft advisory from the Food and Drug Administration and the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline.main: Federal Draft Advisory Warns Some People to Limit Tuna

docs.abstract: FDA and EPA advise limit on amount of tuna consumed by pregnant women, nursing mothers and young children, because of mercury levels that could damage developing nervous system; suggests 12 ounces of fish and shellfish weekly; note that tuna steak and canned albacore tuna generally contain more mercury than canned light tuna (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When my twin sons were born 34 years ago, the goal of every woman I knew, myself included, was a vaginal delivery. Alas, for me, that was not to be: the babies were just too big to make it through my narrow pelvis, and after a nightlong labor they had to be delivered surgically by Caesarean section.

headline.main: With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column explores growing trend of women having elective Caesarean deliveries rather than vaginal births; describes common reasons why mother might choose Caesarean, including convenience, safety and comfort of baby and mother; holds that many common concerns about vaginal deliveries are not supported by research data; Dr W Benson Harer of American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists holds that deciding factor between Caesarean and vaginal births should be mother's preference; graph (M)
